You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the employment-to-population ratio and the participation rate were both around record highs, and measures of spare capacity in the labour market were near their lowest levels in decades.\n                "}]

sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the latest cpi data were regarded as providing confirmation that prices had indeed increased more modestly over the past six months than had been the case around the middle of 2006.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that inflation has decreased, which is a dovish indicator as it may lead to a more accommodative monetary policy."
}

spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: while the stock of unsold new houses was falling, it remained well above the average of the past two decades.\n                "}]

If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: spare capacity in the labour market appeared to have been fully absorbed in japan, the united states and germany, although some spare capacity appeared to remain in other parts of the euro area.\n                "}]

``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: core inflation had continued to edge higher, but remained below the bank of japan's 2\xa0per cent target.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: if there were another serious economic setback, a different set of options would need to be considered.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that the RBA would consider alternative options in the event of an economic setback, suggesting a willingness to accommodate economic support."
}

``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: banks were still keenly bidding for deposits across the yield curve.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that banks are competing for deposits, which suggests a low interest rate environment, indicating a dovish stance."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of 2025-05-04 02:14:04,121 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Reserve Bank of Australia\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: overall, data on the domestic economy appeared to be broadly consistent with the bank's most recent forecasts.\n                "}]
